page.title: 02LANDSCAPE 1
page.content: The{River Stour}follows a natural course winding across its floodplain through the Stourmouth area. Its most important use to the community is as a drain, as most of the area is prone to flooding in the winter. Secondly for {irrigation;}water is taken off through a complex system of dykes to render the marshes fertile in even the dryest summer.The{Little Stour}(part of the course of which is man made) performs a similar function, draining another valley. Both rivers were used for communication until this century.Today the secondary use of the waterways is for{recreation.}Anglers prize the Stour for its specimen Bream and Roach.Clubs come from all over the country to fish these waters. Boatowners have moorings at Plucks Gutter.Hikers and naturalist walk the banks.
